title: 1. The Present Tense (Präsens)
content:
# The Present Tense (Präsens)

In German, the present tense (*Präsens*) is used to talk about what is happening now, what happens regularly, and even future events.

## Conjugation

To conjugate a regular verb, remove the **-en** ending and add the following endings:

| Person | Ending | Example (machen) |
|---|---|---|
| ich | -e | mache |
| du | -st | machst |
| er/sie/es | -t | macht |
| wir | -en | machen |
| ihr | -t | macht |
| sie/Sie | -en | machen |

### Examples
- **Ich spiele Fußball.** (I play soccer.)
- **Er lernt Deutsch.** (He is learning German.)

title: 2. The Definite Articles (Der, Die, Das)
content:
# Definite Articles

German nouns have three genders: Masculine, Feminine, and Neuter. The article changes depending on the gender.

| Gender | Article | Example |
|---|---|---|
| Masculine | der | der Mann (the man) |
| Feminine | die | die Frau (the woman) |
| Neuter | das | das Kind (the child) |
| Plural | die | die Kinder (the children) |

**Tip:** Always learn the article with the noun!

title: 3. The Accusative Case (Akkusativ)
content:
# The Accusative Case

The Accusative case is used for the **direct object** of a sentence (the thing being acted upon).

## Article Changes

Only the **masculine** article changes in the Accusative.

| Gender | Nominative | Accusative |
|---|---|---|
| Masculine | der | **den** |
| Feminine | die | die |
| Neuter | das | das |
| Plural | die | die |

### Examples
- Ich habe **einen** Hund. (I have a dog.)
- Er sieht **den** Mann. (He sees the man.)

title: 4. The Dative Case (Dativ)
content:
# The Dative Case

The Dative case is used for the **indirect object** (to whom/for whom something is done).

## Article Changes

| Gender | Nominative | Dative |
|---|---|---|
| Masculine | der | **dem** |
| Feminine | die | **der** |
| Neuter | das | **dem** |
| Plural | die | **den** (+n to noun) |

### Examples
- Ich gebe **dem** Mann das Buch. (I give the book to the man.)
- Wir helfen **der** Frau. (We help the woman.)

title: 5. Modal Verbs (Müssen, Können, Wollen)
content:
# Modal Verbs

Modal verbs modify the main verb. The modal verb is conjugated in the second position, and the main verb goes to the **end** of the sentence in the infinitive form.

## Common Modals
- **können** (can/be able to)
- **müssen** (must/have to)
- **wollen** (want to)
- **dürfen** (may/be allowed to)
- **sollen** (should)

### Structure
**Subject + Modal Verb + ... + Main Verb (Infinitive)**

- Ich **kann** gut **schwimmen**. (I can swim well.)
- Wir **müssen** jetzt **gehen**. (We must go now.)

title: 6. The Perfect Tense (Perfekt)
content:
# The Perfect Tense (Perfekt)

The *Perfekt* is the most common past tense in spoken German.

## Formation
It is formed with a helper verb (**haben** or **sein**) + the **Partizip II** (past participle) at the end.

### Helper Verbs
- **sein**: For movement (gehen, fahren) or state change (aufwachen).
- **haben**: For most other verbs.

### Examples
- Ich **habe** Fußball **gespielt**. (I played soccer.)
- Er **ist** nach Hause **gegangen**. (He went home.)

title: 7. Prepositions with Accusative
content:
# Prepositions with Accusative

These prepositions *always* trigger the Accusative case:

- **durch** (through)
- **für** (for)
- **gegen** (against)
- **ohne** (without)
- **um** (around/at)

### Examples
- Das Geschenk ist **für dich**. (The gift is for you.)
- Wir gehen **durch den** Park. (We go through the park.)

title: 8. Prepositions with Dative
content:
# Prepositions with Dative

These prepositions *always* trigger the Dative case:

- **aus** (out of/from)
- **bei** (at/with)
- **mit** (with)
- **nach** (after/to)
- **seit** (since)
- **von** (from/of)
- **zu** (to)

### Examples
- Ich komme **aus der** Türkei. (I come from Turkey.)
- Er fährt **mit dem** Bus. (He goes by bus.)

title: 9. Two-Way Prepositions (Wechselpräpositionen)
content:
# Two-Way Prepositions

These prepositions can take **Accusative** (movement/direction) or **Dative** (location/position).

**List:** an, auf, hinter, in, neben, über, unter, vor, zwischen

## The Rule
- **Wohin? (Where to?)** -> **Accusative**
  - Ich lege das Buch **auf den** Tisch. (Action/Movement)
- **Wo? (Where?)** -> **Dative**
  - Das Buch liegt **auf dem** Tisch. (Location)

title: 10. Simple Past (Präteritum)
content:
# Simple Past (Präteritum)

The *Präteritum* is mostly used in written German (books, newspapers) and for helper/modal verbs in speech.

## Helper Verbs
- **sein** -> war (was)
- **haben** -> hatte (had)

### Examples
- Ich **war** müde. (I was tired.)
- Er **hatte** keine Zeit. (He had no time.)

## Regular Verbs
Add **-te** endings (sagte, machte).
- Er **sagte** hallo. (He said hello.)
